title: A Customer-First Approach to Airline Ticketing
excerpt: What if airlines adopted a pay-on-delivery model? Ann Cederhall explores how modernizing ticketing could transform the customer experience.
author: Retailaer
content:
From our reading list: We love Ann Cederhall's thought leadership on airline retailing. This piece resonates deeply with Retailaer's customer-first philosophy—the idea that airlines should rethink legacy processes from the traveler's perspective, not just optimize existing systems.

Rethinking the Ticket

The pandemic exposed critical inefficiencies in airline systems—thousands of unused tickets, vouchers, and refund processing nightmares. Ticket reissuing processes remain expensive and cumbersome, with complex fare rules limiting operational flexibility.

A Pay-on-Delivery Model

Ann proposes adopting pay-on-delivery concepts inspired by retail innovations and blockchain technology:

  • Customers pay for reservations upfront
  • Payment platforms hold funds until service delivery
  • No tickets issued until check-in or departure
  • Changes avoid costly reissues
  • EMDs only issued when services are consumed

The Benefits

This approach could dramatically reduce airline costs for refunds and reissues, simplify complaint handling, decrease the need for clearing houses and auditing, and—most importantly—improve the customer experience.

Ann advocates for blockchain solutions like Chain4Travel/CAMINO to support this transformation without traditional payment intermediaries. Airlines transitioning from ticket/EMD systems to order-based models will have significant competitive advantages.
